posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I was wondering where your teams use socket head screws and where you use button head screws.  Any advice would be appreciated!

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: In general we prefer button head screws because they look cleaner and provide a lower-profile, smoother surface (less risk of entanglement). That said, the main drawback to Button head vs Socket head is you will basically always have to use a smaller driver, meaning there’s more risk of stripping out the head. Also, Socket head screws tend to be more generally available (and cheaper) in longer sizes in my experience, so if you need something really long you might not have any other choice.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Used buttons for decorative surfaces or when smoothness is required.

Used sockets when you need more holding force; they take more torque because they take a larger wrench.

Button heads in areas with limited clearance or in game piece paths.

Socket heads everywhere else as they are much harder to strip.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: We frequently use washers under the socket cap screws since the surface area is smaller than for the button head type, especially for higher stress applications.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
I’m going to have to be an engineer here and go option C:

Y’all are ignoring hex head screws, some of them with built-in flanges so you don’t need washers. Use when you need even more torque and less strippability, but beware that Allen keys don’t work with them.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
Are people really running into scenarios where the maximum torque on a button-head screw is low enough to cause issues? I can think of very few applications where screws would see so much tensile load that the appropriate preload requires a socket cap. It’s almost always possible and preferable to design for the hardware to be loaded mainly in shear. The only other reason to increase preload is for better vibration resistance, but we’re all using more reliable locking options, right? (Nylock nuts, loctite, nylon patch screws, deformed thread inserts, etc.)

Button heads minimize necessary clearance and reduce the risk of collisions/interference.

Personally, my selection process for general bolt head selections is two steps:

Is the bolt being used on a polycarb part where a nylock nut isn’t an option, e.g. through a plate into a standoff, where you would typically use loctite if not for the polycarb? If yes, use a button head nylon patch screw, e.g. McMaster-Carr . If no,

Do I want a washer? If yes, use a flanged button head, e.g. McMaster-Carr . Otherwise use a regular button head screw.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
Another good option for plastic for us has been using the vibratite vc-3

https://a.co/d/iyjE1s9

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Vibra-TITE 213 Red VC-3 Original Threadmate, 250ml Can : Automotive

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

Are people really running into scenarios where the maximum torque on a button-head screw is low enough to cause issues

The reason why I (and I’m guessing most people on this thread) sometimes need to apply a lot of torque to a bolt is because sometimes overzealous students will tighten a bolt way more than is necessary, and often with way too much loctite. Then, if you need to remove that bolt, it’s easier to apply a lot of torque to a socket head then a button head

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: It’s also less prone to rounding when geometry dictates that you need to use a ball-end driver at a slight angle (due to something being in the way).

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: and here I thought everyone was using buttonheads for weight savings…

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Brennyn
posts.cooked: we try to use socket as much as we can for more holding force but we use buttons on places like rollers and elevator rails to reduce the chance of getting caught on something.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

Are people really running into scenarios where the maximum torque on a button-head screw is low enough to cause issues? I can think of very few applications where screws would see so much tensile load that the appropriate preload requires a socket cap.

Do you assemble everything with a torque wrench and a calculated required holding force?

I have experienced plenty of scenarios where high schoolers will over tighten a socket head and end up stripping it, particularly on elements that are disassembled or adjusted at various intervals.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Frankly, the biggest reason I dislike button heads is because we tend to strip them.  The biggest culprit of that is rounded off hex wrenches.  Our members don’t have perfect technique - they’re learning.  As a result, many of our hex wrenches are rounded.  When we catch them we touch them up on the grinder, but button heads tend to strip out the heads much easier than socket with worn allex wrenches.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: The key to button heads that are actually resistant to stripping the hex is to use black oxide alloy steel other high strength steel fasteners instead of the cheapo stainless bolts.  The difference is massive in the required torque to strip.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
BHCS use a smaller drive size with a lower length of engagement vs SHCS, so BHCS cannot sustain as much torque during installation as SHCS. BHCS develop less bolt tension for the same torque vs SHCS because their head diameter is greater (see r_b in equation below). BHCS usually cost more than SHCS* (I know we don’t really care about this in FRC , but it is noteworthy in some industries).

BHCS

Lower installation torque

Less tension for a given torque

More expensive

SHCS

Higher installation torque

More tension for a given torque

Less expensive

I only use BHCS where absolutely necessary. I prefer using SHCS whenever possible. If you really need to go low-profile a countersunk screw is a great option. It has a similar r_b to a BHCS, same drive size as a BHCS, but more drive engagement depth*, and is cheaper than both a BHCS and SHCS*. So it winds up providing better clamping force with a lower chance of stripping vs BHCS.

Looking at 1in long, fully-threaded,  black oxide coated, 10-32 fasteners on McMaster.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
10-32 SHCS and 1/4-20 BHCS

Why? They use the same driver.

The only exceptions are flat heads for a flush finish on select use cases or 10-32 BHCS when required for a catch free finish and can’t counter-sink. Rarely used are #4 or #6 screws for very specific applications.

10-32s are strong enough for 95% of the robot needs. But 1/4-20 fits into Churro shaft.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

Is the bolt being used on a polycarb part where a nylock nut isn’t an option, e.g. through a plate into a standoff, where you would typically use loctite if not for the polycarb?

Gel cyanoacrylate (super glue) can be a valuable tool here.  Safe for the polycarb and removeable with hand tools (plus being low cost and readily available).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.name: Kara Bakowski
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

Are people really running into scenarios where the maximum torque on a button-head screw is low enough to cause issues?

In addition to what @SndMndBdy said…

Overzealous students working with 8-32 button heads/4-40 socket heads (thin shaft collars) or smaller (thankfully, for these really small ones, most times we’ll strip the allen wrench before the head)

Trying to tighten a shaft collar that’s out of tolerance and won’t freaking tighten

Not realizing you’re bottoming out on a threaded hole (blind or through)

Trying to get something really really tight where you can’t use loctite

Bolt is experiencing unexpected shear loading

Accidentally using the wrong size allen, like a metric one that’s really close to the right size, but just barely not it

Most times we’ll strip the head trying to loosen. I think I usually have to get the dremel out for 2-3 stripped bolts a season; thankfully we’re pretty good at catching ones that are “close” when putting them in.

EricH:

Y’all are ignoring hex head screws, some of them with built-in flanges so you don’t need washers. Use when you need even more torque and less strippability, but beware that Allen keys don’t work with them

love me some hex heads, but nut drivers/sockets/wrenches don’t fit in tight spaces so well (that being said, there is also the flavor of tight space where a wrench clears, but there’s no way to get an allen in, but that’s generally not the kind of spot you’d be using a small BH/SH in anyways…)

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: One underrated thing about socket head screws is that it’s just easier to get the driver into the head. If noticed that, with button head screws, students are much more likely to say “I tried that one already” when I hand them the correct driver.

data.title: Socket head vs. button head screws
data.fancy_title: Socket head vs. button head screws

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Used buttons for decorative surfaces or when smoothness is required. 
Used sockets when you need more holding force; they take more torque because they take a larger wrench.
